name: Fioretta
author: KesieV
description: Stefano 'il Kusagari' Fioretto, one of my best gamer friends, gifted me with Bloodborne, the well known Playstation 4 exclusive spin-off of the Souls series, for my birthday. He handed me that game with that predictable grim smile on his face. He knew that I was dodging the Souls series due to its difficulty but he quickly explained its reasons with a new serious face after a short while: 'It's not true that it is that hard and a Castlevania lover like you can't skip this game'. I played that to the end and I've to say that Stefano was damn right and I'll thank him forever. But was Bloodborne good? And how? Most of the gameplay is based on walking around and triggering enemies aggro. I felt that enemies, after meeting the player, started choosing a random move from their set and then perform it: the player have to dodge them and find the right time to attack. These mechanics are quite anachrnonistic for a full retail game, since we can find aggro-and-run games like Gauntlet back in the 1985. But it's some weak criticism, since - hey - it worked well on Gauntlet and the same is for Bloodborne. But, probably, the secret sauce for Bloodborne hardness and satisfaction lies in the enemies behaviour: random selection of hard to read attacks mixes up reflex and gambling. I felt like playing videopoker: for the first hands you feel that you're playing your cards well and that's why you're winning but then you start feeling the weight of randomness, adding some fatalism when evaluating outcomes, breaking the magic and, surprisingly, the tension. Keeping this mix balanced justifies some other strange design decisions: bossess are randomly scattered around the game, without sorting them by difficulty (i.e. I've found the first boss harder than the others), summoned hunters, which are supposed to help you, are way too much dumb, RPG elements are not so effective and helping NPCs on their quests (which will gift you with helpful items later) in hard and really unclear. The suggested Castlevania influences are there and very noticeable: enemy, environment ahestetics and map design resembles the ones of Symphony Of The Night (1997) so much that an entire part of the game, Castle Cainhurst, is a love letter to that series, from the first cutscene to the end. But the most crucial influence comes from H.P. Lovecraft, 1890's greatest horror novelist, which is so deep that most of the game confusing plot is understandable only if you're a very devoted reader. So: old mechanics, gambling, strong influences from other games and mandatory American narrative knowledge. Is this bad or hard? Don't fall into the critics trap again: there isn't a right answer. I had a lot of fun, despite the swearing and once into the right mood, and I'll surely get its next chapter, when it will come out. Plot! You fell in a strange dark world. Where is it? Who are you? What are you supposed to do and why? On the intro screen use A BUTTON for loading your previous game (if any) or DOWN for starting a new one. Use LEFT/RIGHT for moving your character and UP for jumping. Hold down the A BUTTON for performing an action: hit UP for attacking with your main weapon and DOWN for the secondary one, RIGHT for healing and LEFT for throwing a rock. This time, Commodore 64 style and audio!

cheats.quickSave: Quicksave with B button (use with care!)

set.message: Ugh. I. Can't. Move. Is... is this the time?

bonusBullets.description: Sun Bullets, like an explosion that greets us from above, must be risen by your smoking pipe.

bonusRock.description: The hallowed Rocks of Ancient Mystic Lore. Use them to tempt the naked purpled breasts.

bonusWine.description: Contains the Soul of Wine. You feel a boundless joy flowing it down.

set.message: Break to switch weapons to Axe/Pistol.
Break to switch weapons to Whip/Shotgun.

object.html:
Press BUTTON to load game.
- or -
Press DOWN to start a new game.

FIORETTA
(c) 2016
A tribute to Bloodborne.


Graphics by:
KesieV Norimaki


Story by:
KesieV Norimaki
Bianca Brenna
Charles

Code by:
KesieV Norimaki

Music by:
Tomasz Szymczak (Randy)
(Music for Monsters - Main theme)
Tomasz Szymczak (Randy)
(After Death - Boss battle theme)


Big thanks to:
Bianca
Il Marsicano
Stefano "Il Kusagari" Fioretto
Romolo Camplani
Fulvio "Iunto" Mastromatteo
All Akihabara age friends










There is a whole and eternal
world in everyone.

object.message: Tight, swarming, like a million worms, A population of Demons carries on in our brains.
The Demon makes secret holes in this abyss, Whence would escape a thousand years of sweat and strain.
You could count in your beds More kisses than fleurs-de-lis And subject to your power Many Valois!
Come, superb cat. My hand tingles with the pleasure Of feeling your electric body.
I was 6 when verses stopped blooming in the fields like roses.

Z p gn II       Z          Z    pp gn p

object.message: Ah, why did I not bear a serpent's nest entire, Instead of bringing forth this hideous Child of Doom!
When by an edict of the powers supreme A poet's born into this world's drab space.

map: Z  I XX      XX I  Z
Z    pp ppp  pp pp Z

object.message: I should have loved to have lived Beside a maiden giantess, Like a luxurious cat at the feet of a queen.

map: Z   gn gn gn p     Z

object.message: You know this dainty monster, too, it seems, hypocrite adventurer!
Poets, before my grandiose poses, Will consume their lives in austere study.
In her grief, The Mother, chaste and thin, was Near her treacherous spouse who was once her lover.
Obeying a curious whim, I had banned studies from that spectacle.

object.message: The thunder and the rain have made such ravage My garden is nigh bare of rosy fruit.
I advance to attack, and I climb to assault, Like a swarm of maggots after a cadaver.

object.message: As an unfathomed sphinx, enthroned by the Nile, My heart a swan's whiteness with granite combines.

object.message: Sweltering Africa and languorous Asia, A whole far-away world, absent, almost defunct.

map: Z  zW   I II Ws -  Z

object.message: Rembrandt, gloomy hospital filled with murmuring, Ornamented only with a large crucifix.

map: Z-- cb   ZXI I I I #

object.message: Kisses and bite, Tortures the breast of an old witch. Steal as we pass by a clandestine pleasure.
I was happy, healthy, and sated; As for me, my arms are weary Because I have embraced the clouds.

object.message: His mother starts, in horror, to blaspheme Clenching her fists at God, who grants her grace.

map: e Z e hhhhh  I  eZ

object.message: Angel of gaiety, have you known anguish, Shame and remorse, tears, boredom, and dismay?
My spirit resembles the tower which crumbles Under the tireless blows of the battering ram.

map: #- k# k k k kkkkk z#

object.message: Oh. I cannot like a love-leaf wantonly Consign this stunted monster to the glowing grate.
Disease and Death make ashes Of all the fire that flamed for us.

map: Z + zwws zs zs zs  Z

object.message: Oh cursed be that transient night of vain desire When I conceived my expiation in my womb!
Far from famous sepulchers Toward a lonely cemetery My heart Goes beating funeral marches.
This world will soon end, at the foot of the delicious terrible catafalque.
The panting swain that o'er his mistress sighs, Seems the Sick, that stroke their gravestones lovingly.

object.message: Thou givest me the beauty of divine caresses. Without pity or mercy we will fight.
